mentions.context: ORI can be easily adapted to other genera or species.
ORI is therefore in line with the principles of a method such as Kraken, although it differs in many ways.

ORI produces a graph that shows the distribution of distances between strains and helps to select a reasonable maximum distance threshold, which leads to grouping of a limited number of strains with close genomes.
ORI identification is almost perfect in each case, with identification of the correct CIRM-BIA67 strain up to 1000 reads and the sibling strain CIRM-BIA65 with more reads.
ORI features three major choices adapted to strain-level identification from long read noisy data.
ORI uses a first identification step for each read, utilizing the fact that all the k-mers in a long read must belong to a single species.
Kraken 2 rarely allows assigning a read at a level below the species because it uses a compression process (minimizers) that reduces the differences between genomes.
Kraken 2 assigned most of the reads to the species S. thermophilus and less than 2 % to strain CIRM-BIA67.
Kraken 2 is clearly less well adapted to the recognition of strains.
Kraken 2 is an excellent choice for large-scale species recognition, based on the use of minimizers.

Metamaps [28], specifically developed for the analysis of metagenomic datasets, also uses alignments to identify species/strains, is designed for long reads and, according to its authors [28], seems more precise than Centrifuge.
StrainSeeker also gives good results and has the best MCC but is penalized by the production of multiple solutions and wider variations than ORI.
StrainSeeker behaves correctly with parameters carefully tuned.
StrainSeeker requires another input, a classification tree on the whole set of genomes guiding the identification process.
